SurveyElements.SecondaryAttribute: Information for Participants Principal Investigator: Dr Catherine Lai Researchers Collecting the

Payload.QuestionText:
Information for Participants 
Principal Investigator: Dr Catherine Lai 
Researchers Collecting the Data: Sarenne Wallbridge 


What is this document? 
This study has been approved by the University of Edinburgh School of Informatics Research Ethics procedure, RT number 2019/25748. Please take time to read the following information carefully. 

Nature of the study
You are invited to participate in a study which involves listening to some speech recordings carefully and answering questions about them. Once you finish, we may have also some questions about your language background and age (year only). Your responses will be recorded. Your session should last for up to 20 minutes. You will be given full instructions shortly. 


Compensation
You will receive £3 to participate in this study. We also pay a separate fee to the service we use to recruit participants, Prolific Academic. 
 
Risks and benefits
There are no known risks to participation in this study. Other than the payment mentioned, there no tangible benefits to you, however, you will be contributing to our knowledge about language. 


Confidentiality

  • The Prolific Academic participant recruitment service does not share your personal information with us. The only information about you that they provide to us is that you are a native speaker of English. 

  • The Qualtrics experiment platform collects and stores your survey responses and your IP address. 

  • The data to which we have access is not associated with your name or with any other personal details that might identify you. Your survey responses will only be available to the researcher(s) named above and their research group within the University of Edinburgh. This data will be stored on the School of Informatics' secure file servers. Although every reasonable effort has been taken, confidentiality during internet communication procedures cannot be guaranteed. 


Voluntary participation and your right to withdraw
Your participation is voluntary. You may stop at any time and for any reason simply by closing your browser window. If you stop participating, data collection will end, but data already collected will be retained. 


Contact information 
This research is being conducted by the above-named researchers at the University of Edinburgh who can be contacted at c.lai@ed.ac.uk. To make a complaint about the study, contact inf-ethics@inf.ed.ac.uk, providing the study title and nature of your complaint. 

 
By accepting this task, you consent to the following: 
1. I agree to participate in this study. 
2. I confirm that I have read and understood how my data will be stored and used. 
3. I understand that I have the right to terminate this session at any point. If I choose to withdraw after completing the study, my data will be deleted at that time.

SurveyElements.SecondaryAttribute: Discriminative Turns When we engage in conversation with another person, we make use of the words...

Payload.QuestionText:
Discriminative Turns

When we engage in conversation with another person, we make use of the words that are spoken as well as the way in which they are said to understand what someone may mean. The exact same phrase can be said in ways that mean completely different things.


Task

During each round of this task, you will be presented with audio segments of conversations between 2 people. Each set of segments contains a real segment that occurred in an actual phone conversation; the rest of have been synthetically constructed. 


Each segment consists of at least a turn and a response, and will be presented as:

The initial turn
The response
 
 
Your task

In each experiment, your task is to select the true segment from the false ones by assigning each audio segment a score of how likely it is to be the true segment, with scores ranging from 'very unlikely', to 'very likely'.
 

Along with the audio segments to choose between, you will receive a varying degree of additional context from the rest of the conversation which you can use to help make your decision.

Payload.QuestionText:
Consider the previous recordings that you just listened to. Please select the gender of the speaker who said:
. . .
[noise]
but well i just i i'm glad we've learned i'm sorry we had the experience of Vietnam
. . .

Consider the following segment of a phone conversation (you will hear the sections in underlined bold):
. . .
yes i do i keep uh i have an American Express and a Visa card that i keep you know kind of for emergency purposes and i have you know i use a gasoline credit card which i you know pay off every every month
um-hum
but i've i've gotten rid of all of the credit cards you know that i possibly could and my balances are practically zero on the ones that i have
okay
especially since you know it's no longer after this year or after tax year nineteen ninety there's there's no deductions for you know credit card interest that you pay so it's a
um-hum
you know gosh credit cards run what anywhere from up to eighteen nineteen percent i guess
yeah
. . .
Only one of the following recordings is the true segment in this conversation. Assign each audio segment a score of how likely it is to be the true segment.

(You can listen to the recordings as many times as you need to make your judgements.)
